title: United Kingdom criminalizes gay sex between men
short_desc: Section 11 of the 1885 Criminal Law Amendment Act was put into effect and criminalized homosexual acts. Under this Act, Oscar Wilde & Alan Turing, among many others, were convicted and punished for committing homosexual acts.

title: Illinois repeals Sodomy Laws
short_desc: Illinois is the first U.S. state to decriminalize homosexuality which came into effect on this day in 1962.

title: Dr. Benjamin publishes book on treatment of transsexuals*
short_desc: Dr. Harry Benjamin publishes first book devoted to a treatment of transsexuals, 'The Transsexual Phenomenon' which becomes an influential voice in defense of the community.
extra: *Transsexual is a term that should never be used to refer to the entire transgender community. The word 'transsexual' was used historically as a medical term to indicate a difference between one's gender identity and the sex assigned at birth. Transgender or Non-binary are more appropriate terms in today's time.

title: Norway legalizes same-sex marriage
short_desc: Norway becomes the sixth country world-wide to legalize same-sex marriage.

title: Kinsey's study of homosexual behavior in men published
short_desc: Dr. Alfred Kinsey publishes "Sexual Behavior in the Human Male," where he states that 10% of men are homosexual for at least some time in their lives. His Kinsey scale and other research was the first widely published research to explore taboos such as masterbation and same-sex sexual behavior.

title: French men executed for Homosexual Activity
short_desc: Bruno Lenoir and Jean Diot are caught having sex in a public space in Paris. A year later they were executed. Their executions were the last in France for consensual sodomy.

title: Harvey Milk takes office
short_desc: Harvey Milk, the first openly gay elected official in California history. Milk became more active in San Francisco politics because he thought the city's gay leadership was too conservative and wished to gain greater political rights for LGBTQ+ people. He was elected to the San Francisco Board of Supervisors.

title: Pride group protest in LA
short_desc: PRIDE, a Los Angeles homophile group, mobilizes a crowd of several hundred demonstrators on Sunset Boulevard to protest a police raid of Black Cat, a gay bar. It was one of the earliest organized gay rights demonstrations in the United States.

title: The Stonewall Riots begin
short_desc: The Stonewall riots (also referred to as the Stonewall uprising or the Stonewall rebellion) were a series of spontaneous demonstrations by members of the gay (LGBT) community in response to a police raid that began in the early morning hours of June 28, 1969, at the Stonewall Inn in the Greenwich Village neighborhood of Manhattan, New York City.

title: Birth of Mary Rozet Smith
short_desc: In 1868, Mary Rozet Smith is born in Chicago. Mary was a U.S. philanthropist and was the companion of activist, Jane Addams for over thirty years. She was a major financial contributor to Hull House, a settlement house in Chicago, Illinois opened to serve recently arrived European immigrants. Many of its residents were female social reformers and activists such as Julia Lathrop and Mary Kenney O'Sullivan.

title: Stormé DeLarverie born
short_desc: Stormé DeLarverie, born on December 24, 1920, was an American woman known as the butch lesbian whose scuffle with police was, according to Stormé and many eyewitnesses, the spark that ignited the Stonewall riots, spurring the crowd to action. She was born in New Orleans, to an African American mother and a white father. She is remembered as a gay civil rights icon and entertainer, who performed and hosted at the Apollo Theater and Radio City Music Hall. She worked for much of her life as an MC, singer, bouncer, bodyguard and volunteer street patrol worker, the "guardian of lesbians in the Village." She is known as "the Rosa Parks of the gay community.

title: Alan Turing pardoned
short_desc: Alan Turing, whose contributions to computer science and artificial intelligence helped the Allies defeat Hitler and the Nazi party in World War II. After the war, in 1952, Turingwas charged with "gross indecency" after the police found out he was in a relationship with another man. In England, homosexuality was a criminal offenceat the time. Instead of choosing prison for pleading guilty, he chose to undergohormonal treatment which left Turing impotent and caused breast tissue to form.On June 9, 1954, Turing took his life. On this day in 2013, Queen Elizabeth II signeda pardon for Turing conviction effective immediately.

title: Ian McKellen: first openly gay man knighted
short_desc: Ian McKellen is knighted by the Queen of England. He is the first openly gay man to be knighted. He is an English actor & recipient of six Laurence Olivier Awards, a Tony Award, a Golden Globe Award, a Screen Actors Guild Award, a BIF Award, two Saturn Awards, four Drama Desk Awards, and two Critics’ Choice Awards. He has also received two Oscar nominations, four BAFTA nominations and five Emmy Awardnominations. While McKellen had made his sexual orientation known to fellow actors early on in his stage career, it was not until 1988 that he came out to the general public.

title: Council on Religion and the Homosexual attendees outed by Police
short_desc: The Council on Religion and the Homosexual holds a costume party at California Hall on Polk Street in San Francisco to raise money for the new organization. When the ministers informed the San Francisco Police Department of the event, the SFPD attempted to force the rented hall’s owners to cancel it. Police attempt to intimidate some 600 guests by photographing each guest as they arrive. Though charges were dropped, the Council published a brief detailing how police oppressed and abused homosexuals.

title: Guinea criminalizes same-sex sexual activity
short_desc: Guinea's Article 325 is added to the penal code making same-sex sexual activity illegal.
